added_lines: import randomimport string # pylint: disable=eval-used class SettingsChanger(object): """ Class for changing cluster settings """ SKIPPED_FIELDS_LIST = [ 'additional_components.mongo', 'storage.osd_pool_size', 'syslog.syslog_port', 'murano_settings.murano_repo_url', 'external_mongo.hosts_ip', 'kernel_params.kernel', 'corosync.port', 'repo_setup.uca_openstack_release', 'repo_setup.uca_repo_url', 'public_ssl.cert_source', 'public_ssl.hostname', 'operator_user.homedir', 'access.email', 'common.libvirt_type', 'storage.images_vcenter', 'additional_components.ironic', 'additional_components.ceilometer', 'workloads_collector.tenant', 'access.user', 'workloads_collector.user', 'operator_user.name'] def __init__(self, attrs=None): self._attrs = attrs['editable'] if attrs else None self._types = ['checkbox', 'radio', 'text', 'textarea'] self.options = None @staticmethod def _gen_random(length=10): return ''.join(random.choice(string.lowercase) for _ in range(length)) @staticmethod def _get_condition(restriction): rst = re.findall( 'settings:(.+?).value ([=!]+) (true|false|\'.+\')', restriction) cmd = [] keys = [] for r in rst: cmd.append("self.options['{opt}'][2] {oper} {sign}".format( opt=r[0], oper=r[1], sign=True if r[2] == 'true' else False if r[2] == 'false' else r[2])) keys.append(r[0]) if ' and ' in restriction: expression = ' and '.join(cmd) elif ' or ' in restriction: expression = ' or '.join(cmd) else: expression = ' '.join(cmd) return expression, keys def __change_check_box(self, key, opt, keys=None): opt['value'] = not self.options[key][2] self.options[key][2] = opt['value'] if keys: for k in keys: self.options[k][5] = False logger.info('`{0}` was changed to `{1}`'.format(key, opt['value'])) def __change_radio(self, key, opt, keys=None): values = self.options[key][3] current_val = self.options[key][2] for val in values: if val['data'] != current_val: opt['value'] = val['data'] self.options[key][2] = opt['value'] if keys: for k in keys: self.options[k][5] = False logger.info( '`{0}` was changed to `{1}`'.format( key, val['data'])) break else: logger.debug( 'Failed to set radio {}'.format(self.options[key][0])) def __change_check_box_restr(self, condition, keys, key, opt): try: if not eval(condition) and self.options[key][5]: self.__change_check_box(key, opt, keys) else: logger.info( "Value `{}` couldn't be changed to `{}` due " "to restrictions".format(key, not self.options[key][2])) except KeyError as e: logger.debug('Value was not found {}'.format(e)) def __change_radio_restr(self, condition, keys, key, opt): try: if not eval(condition) and self.options[key][5]: self.__change_radio(key, opt, keys) except KeyError as e: logger.debug('Value was not found {}'.format(e)) def _make_change_wo_restr(self, key, opt): tp = opt.get('type') if tp == 'checkbox': self.__change_check_box(key, opt) elif tp == 'radio': self.__change_radio(key, opt) elif tp == 'text': opt['value'] = self._gen_random() self.options[key][2] = opt['value'] logger.info('`{0}` was changed to `{1}`'.format(key, opt['value'])) def _make_change_with_restr(self, key, opt): restrictions = self.options[key][4] tp = opt.get('type') if not restrictions: return for rest in restrictions: condition, keys = self._get_condition(rest) if tp == 'checkbox': self.__change_check_box_restr(condition, keys, key, opt) elif tp == 'radio': self.__change_radio_restr(condition, keys, key, opt) elif tp == 'text': logger.debug('Did you forget me `{}`?'.format(key)) def _change_options(self, options, restr=False, ensure=False): if not (restr or ensure): change_func = self._make_change_wo_restr elif restr and not ensure: change_func = self._make_change_with_restr else: change_func = self._ensure_options_correct for attr in self._attrs: for option in self._attrs[attr]: key = '.'.join([attr, option]) if key not in options: continue # skip some values if key in self.SKIPPED_FIELDS_LIST: logger.debug("Skipped option `{}`".format(key)) continue opt = self._attrs[attr][option] change_func(key, opt) def _ensure_options_correct(self, key, opt): restrictions = self.options[key][4] tp = opt.get('type') if not restrictions: return for rest in restrictions: condition, _ = self._get_condition(rest) if tp == 'checkbox': try: if eval(condition) and self.options[key][2]: self.__change_check_box(key, opt) except KeyError as e: logger.debug('Value was not found {}'.format(e)) elif tp == 'radio': logger.info('Radio `{0}` has value `{1}` when restriction ' 'is: {2}'.format(key, opt['value'], condition)) elif tp == 'text': logger.info('Do I rely on anything `{}`?'.format(key)) @staticmethod def _calculate_options(options, randomize=None): if randomize: count = randomize if randomize < len(options) else len(options) - 1 random_keys = random.sample(options.keys(), count) options_wo_restr = \ {opt: options[opt] for opt in options if opt in random_keys and options[opt][4] is None} options_with_restr = \ {opt: options[opt] for opt in options if opt in random_keys and options[opt][4] is not None} else: options_wo_restr = \ {opt: options[opt] for opt in options if options[opt][4] is None} options_with_restr = \ {opt: options[opt] for opt in options if options[opt][4] is not None} return options_wo_restr, options_with_restr def make_changes(self, attrs=None, options=None, randomize=None): """ Function makes changes in cluster settings in paramsters which are presented in options list :param attrs: cluster attributes :param options: dict with options provided by parser :param randomize: specify if random changing is needed :return: changed cluster attributes """ if attrs: self.attrs = attrs # Create two dicts with options without restrictions and with them self.options = options if options else self.parse_settings() opt_wo_restr, opt_with_restr = \ self._calculate_options(self.options, randomize) # First of all lets modify values without restrictions logger.info("Changing options without restrictions") self._change_options(opt_wo_restr, False) self.options.update(opt_wo_restr) # iterate through options with restrictions logger.info("Changing options with restrictions") self._change_options(opt_with_restr, True) logger.info("Check options for invalid due to restrictions " "and modify it if it's necessary") self.options.update(opt_with_restr) self._change_options(self.options, True, True) return self.attrs def load_settings_from_file(self, file_name, file_type='json'): """ Function loads settings from file :param file_name: file to load from :param file_type: file format `json` or `yaml` :return: nothing """ try: with open(file_name, 'r') as f: if file_type == 'json': self.attrs = json.load(f) else: self.attrs = yaml.load(f) except ValueError: logger.error("Check settings file for consistency") raise except IOError: logger.error("Check settings file existence") raise else: logger.info('Settings were loaded from file {}'.format(file_name)) def save_settings_to_file(self, file_name, file_type='json'): """ Function saves settings to file :param file_name: file to save to :param file_type: file format `json` or `yaml` :return: nothing """ with open(file_name, 'w') as f: if file_type == 'json': json.dump(self.attrs, f) else: yaml.dump(self.attrs, f) logger.info('Settings were saved to file {}'.format(file_name)) # pylint: disable=too-many-nested-blocks def parse_settings(self, attrs=None): """ Function parses attributes by its type :param attrs: a cluster attributes :return: a dict with options """ attrs = attrs['editable'] if attrs else self._attrs self.options = {} for attr in attrs: for option in attrs[attr]: key = '.'.join([attr, option]) opt = attrs[attr][option] tp = opt.get('type') label = opt.get('label') value = opt.get('value') values = opt.get('values') restrictions = opt.get('restrictions', None) if tp not in self._types: continue if key in self.options: logger.debug('`{0}` has duplicates'.format(key)) continue restr = None if restrictions: restr = [] for rest in restrictions: if isinstance(rest, dict): if rest.get('condition') \ and 'value' in rest['condition']: restr.append(rest['condition']) elif 'value' in rest.keys()[0]: restr.append(rest.keys()[0]) elif 'value' in rest: restr.append(rest) else: restr.append(rest) self.options[key] = \ [label, tp, value, values, restr if restr else None, True] logger.debug( 'Option {0} has been added with {1}'.format( key, self.options[key])) return self.options # pylint: enable=too-many-nested-blocks @property def attrs(self): dct = dict() dct['editable'] = self._attrs return dct @attrs.setter def attrs(self, attrs): self._attrs = attrs['editable'] # pylint: enable=eval-used

commit_message:
Add Ops repo to OpenStack-Ansible

At the Austin summit it was agreed that OpenStack-Ansible should
have a repository to facilitate the sharing of various scripts/tips
which may be useful to operators or developers when using
OpenStack-Ansible.

This patch creates the repository for the project and sets up the
basic jobs for it.

Needed-By: Ib6cd1afcdee502a0819c1afb7b27f27f8f96b381
Change-Id: I96a582d73871c9f479619e5492764919c424e7a1

commit_message:
Add overcloud VIP to sshuttle config

Overcloud VIP in overcloudrs is 10.0.0.4/32, and should be
included in sshuttle forwarding, keystone listens on this
IP address only.

Change-Id: I5d0e9e24ee2d858997929b8e659adced7a4f7482

commit_message:
VMware: Enable memory, disk and vnic limits

Re-proposing this spec from mitaka to complete
the implementation for blueprint vmware-limits-newton.

Pending items:
- configure vif limits when attaching interfaces
- configure limits during resize operation
- expose the limits configuration parameters via image metadata

Change-Id: Ice28f0122bf5b2640fec622121156af3a6fdf88e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/85/315685/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== VMware Limits, Shares and Reservations ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-limits-mitaka VMware Virtual Center provides options to specify limits, reservations and shares for CPU, memory, disks and network adapters. In the Juno cycle support for CPU limits, reservation and shares was added. This blueprint proposes a way of supporting memory, disk and network limits, reservations and shares. For limits the utlization will not exceed the limit. Reservations will be guaranteed for the instance. Shares are used to determine relative allocation between resource consumers. In general, a consumer with more shares gets proportionally more of the resource, subject to certain other constraints. Problem description =================== The VMware driver is only able to support CPU limits. Providing admins the ability to provide limits, reservation and shares for memory, disks and network adapters will be a very useful tool for providing QoS to tenants. Use Cases ---------- * This will enable a cloud provider to provide SLA's to customers * It will allow tenants to be guaranteed performance Proposed change =============== Due to the different models for different drivers and the API's in which the backends expose we are unable to leverage the same existings flavor extra specs. For example for devices libvirt makes use of: 'hw_rng:rate_bytes', 'hw_rng:rate_period'. In addition to this there are the following disk I/O options are: 'disk_read_bytes_sec', 'disk_read_iops_sec', 'disk_write_bytes_sec', 'disk_write_iops_sec', 'disk_total_bytes_sec', and 'disk_total_iops_sec'. For bandwidth limitations there is the 'rxtx_factor'. This will not enable us to provide the limits, reservations and shares for vifs. This is used in some bases to pass the information through to Neutron so that the backend network can do the limitations. The following extra_specs can be configured for bandwidth I/O for vifs: 'vif_inbound_average', 'vif_inbound_burst', 'vif_inbound_peak', 'vif_outbound_average', 'vif_outbound_burst' and 'vif_outbound_peak'. None of the above of possible for the VMware driver due to VC API's. The following additions below are proposed: Limits, reservations and shares will be exposed for the following: * memory * disks * network adapters The flavor extra specs for quotas has been extended to support: * quota:memory_limit - The memory utilization of a virtual machine will not exceed this limit, even if there are available resources. This is typically used to ensure a consistent performance of virtual machines independent of available resources. Units are MB. * quota:memory_reservation - guaranteed minimum reservation (MB) * quota:memory_shares_level - the allocation level. This can be 'custom', 'high' 'normal' or 'low'. * quota:memory_shares_share - in the event that 'custom' is used, this is the number of shares. * quota:disk_io_limit - The I/O utilization of a virtual machine will not exceed this limit. The unit is number of I/O per second. * quota:disk_io_reservation - Reservation control is used to provide guaranteed allocation in terms of IOPS * quota:disk_io_shares_level - the allocation level. This can be 'custom', 'high' 'normal' or 'low'. * quota:disk_io_shares_share - in the event that 'custom' is used, this is the number of shares. * quota:vif_limit - The bandwidth limit for the virtual network adapter. The utilization of the virtual network adapter will not exceed this limit, even if there are available resources. Units in Mbits/sec. * quota:vif_reservation - Amount of network bandwidth that is guaranteed to the virtual network adapter. If utilization is less than reservation, the resource can be used by other virtual network adapters. Reservation is not allowed to exceed the value of limit if limit is set. Units in Mbits/sec. * quota:vif_shares_level - the allocation level. This can be 'custom', 'high' 'normal' or 'low'. * quota:vif_shares_share - in the event that 'custom' is used, this is the number of shares. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is to create an abstract user concept that could help hide the details and of the difference from end users, and isolate the differences to just the admin users. This is really out of the scope of what is proposed and will take a huge cross driver effort. This will not only be relevant for flavors but maybe for images too. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Preventing instances from exhausting storage resources can have a significant performance impact. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: garyk Work Items ---------- * common objects for limits, reservation and shares * memory support * disk support * vif support Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This will be tested by the VMware CI. We will add tests to validate this. Documentation Impact ==================== This should be documented in the VMware section. References ========== The vCenter API's can be see the following links: * Disk IO: http://goo.gl/uepivS * Memory: http://goo.gl/6sHwIA * Network Adapters: http://goo.gl/c2amhq History ======= None

commit_message:
Add ability to calculate MTU for bridge,

if MTU described only into "interfaces" section

Also convert fixtures to YAML format

Change-Id: Idfa4cbd5672a21d651be349b9b3602b0498173e5
Closes-bug: #1575762
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/79/320979/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEFAULT_MTU ||= 1500 def get_mtu_for_bridge(br_name, network_scheme, inspected_bridges) mtu = nil # in this chain patch should be last, because ports and bonds has highest priority {'add-port' => 'bridge' , 'add-bond' => 'bridge', 'add-patch' => 'bridges'}.each do |x , v| transf = network_scheme['transformations'].select do |trans| trans['action']==x and trans.has_key?(v) and (trans[v]==br_name or trans[v].include?(br_name)) end if transf.empty? next elsif transf.size >2 raise("bridge #{br_name} can not be included into more then one element, elements: #{transf}") else transf = transf[0] debug("Transformation #{transf} has bridge #{br_name}") end if transf['action'] == 'add-patch' debug("Bridge #{br_name} is in a patch #{transf}!") next_br_name = transf['bridges'].select{ |x| x!=br_name }[0] if ! inspected_bridges.include?(br_name) debug("Looking mtu for bridge #{next_br_name}") inspected_bridges << br_name mtu = get_mtu_for_bridge(next_br_name, network_scheme, inspected_bridges) else next end elsif !transf['mtu'].nil? # this section into elsif, because patch MTU shouldn't affect result (MTU 65000 for example) mtu = transf['mtu'] elsif transf['action']=='add-port' and !network_scheme['interfaces'].fetch(transf['name'],{}).fetch('mtu',nil).nil? mtu = network_scheme['interfaces'][transf['name']]['mtu'] end if !mtu.nil? debug("And has mtu: #{mtu}") break end end mtu ||= DEFAULT_MTU return mtu end mtu = get_mtu_for_bridge(br['name'], network_scheme, []) physnet_mtu_map[net] = mtu
deleted_lines: bridge_including_flow = { :'add-patch' => 'bridges', :'add-port' => 'bridge' , :'add-bond' => 'bridge', :'add-port' => 'bridge' } br = br['name'] bridge_including_flow.each do |x , v| bridge_included = network_scheme['transformations'].select { |a| a['action'] == x.to_s and a.has_key?(v) and (a[v] == br or a[v].include?(br)) } if bridge_included.empty? next elsif bridge_included.size >2 raise("bridge #{br} can not be included into more then one element, elements: #{bridge_included}") else bridge_included = bridge_included[0] debug("Transformation #{bridge_included} has bridge #{br}") end if bridge_included['action'] == 'add-patch' debug("Bridge #{br} is in a patch #{bridge_included}!") br = bridge_included['bridges'].select{ |x| x!=br }[0] debug("Looking mtu for bridge #{br}") next elsif bridge_included['mtu'] mtu = bridge_included['mtu'] debug("And has mtu: #{mtu}") break end end mtu = 1500 unless mtu physnet_mtu_map[net] = mtu

commit_message:
Ensure ryu and ovs are compatible

As ryu>=4.1 depends on ovs>=2.6.0.dev0, update the ovs package
constraints. In particular, on python2.7 we need to allow ovs 2.6.0 to
be installed.

Closes-Bug: 1584858

Change-Id: I6d2796a1aba3e0a299291946b4c9c4169fa00923

commit_message:
Support of Ubuntu 16.04 LTS Xenial deployments

Add support for Xenial deployments.

* Disable SSL on Ubuntu Xenial deployments.
* Pin puppetlabs-mysql to a recent commit (until they produce a new
  tag).
* Disable Ceph on Ubuntu Xenial deployments, neither Hammer or Jewel currently
  work out of the box with puppet-ceph on Xenial.
* Disable Horizon on Ubuntu Xenial deployments: not working yet.
* Do not deploy UCA on Xenial, since we currently deploy Mitaka.
* On Xenial, deploy Puppet using distro packaging, not puppetlabs.com.
* Cleanup /etc/default/puppet on Xenial / Puppet4 runs (workaround)
  until we figure what is installing this file on Xenial nodepool
  image.

All issues are documented here:
See https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/puppet-openstack-xenial

Change-Id: Ifc8c7e241add830c88b84c1f01770e5e15df1653
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/30/308530/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Mitaka is already packaged in 16.04, so we don't need UCA. if ($::operatingsystem == 'Ubuntu') and ! (versioncmp($::operatingsystemmajrelease, '16') >= 0) { class { '::openstack_extras::repo::debian::ubuntu': repo => 'proposed', release => 'mitaka', # drop this line when mitaka is stable released package_require => true, } # Ceph is both packaged on UCA & ceph.com # Official packages are on ceph.com so we want to make sure # Ceph will be installed from there. apt::pin { 'ceph': priority => 1001, origin => 'download.ceph.com', }
deleted_lines: class { '::openstack_extras::repo::debian::ubuntu': repo => 'proposed', release => 'mitaka', # drop this line when mitaka is stable released package_require => true, } # Ceph is both packaged on UCA & ceph.com # Official packages are on ceph.com so we want to make sure # Ceph will be installed from there. apt::pin { 'ceph': priority => 1001, origin => 'download.ceph.com',

it from there.

subject: Completed migrations are not "in progress"
revisions:

This fixes an issue where we consider migrations that have been completed
as "in progress" by not filtering them out of the result set from
migration_get_in_progress_by_host_and_node(). This adds that state to
the list and adds a migration in that state to the test case. If it
is not filtered, the counts won't line up and the test will fail.

Closes-Bug: #1583720
'}]
commit_message:
Completed migrations are not "in progress"

This fixes an issue where we consider migrations that have been completed
as "in progress" by not filtering them out of the result set from
migration_get_in_progress_by_host_and_node(). This adds that state to
the list and adds a migration in that state to the test case. If it
is not filtered, the counts won't line up and the test will fail.

Change-Id: I7aafab9abdbfafe9479846f06068ba8a963d290a
Closes-Bug: #1583720

commit_message:
MySQL OCF stop check for sst as well

Fix action stop to consider MySQL not running if only there is no
SST and no pid found.
Fix proc_stop command to match mysqld by its datadir, fix its stop
retry count and wait timeout

Change-Id: If4e54f0cd656360268f55bdce7a2c1f5a506ece2
Closes-bug: #1585125
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/91/320491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local rc # if there is no pid AND no SST found, consider it not running # otherwise it may be running an SST and shall be stopped check_if_sst rc=$? if [ $rc -ne $OCF_SUCCESS -a ! -f $OCF_RESKEY_pid ]; then proc_stop "${OCF_RESKEY_pid_file}" "mysqld.*${OCF_RESKEY_datadir}" SIGTERM 5 $(( $shutdown_timeout/5 ))

commit_message:
Change node name from CLI (fuel1)

Added possibility to change node name:
`fuel node --node-id --name NewName`
The functionality for fuel2 has been already merged
in separate patch.

Also unit tests added.

Change-Id: I6d3384d1615bdd1dbb53508a0c2908e62f05898b
Partial-Bug: #1498523
(cherry picked from commit 6810231ec6d333fc10f7020f9bdf5122e05e998a)
added some requirement for tests

commit_message:
Set AIO to use an OpenStack-Infra wheel mirror

To speed up an AIO build when *not* executed in the OpenStack-CI gate,
this patch determines the fastest available wheel mirror and includes
it as an extra pip index.

This speeds up the repo build process by ensuring that the wheels do
not need to be built locally, but can simply be downloaded from the
mirror.

The patch also includes some clean up which was left out of
I73fa1db5210f02d6df9dc324f8b4ec21232d06ba relating to apt conf files.

Change-Id: I56f7c8520cc6cec74df5ca8611d988039184efbb

This can be used to test that basic rendering works for these examples, so if someone breaks something we know. """ @with_app(buildername='html', srcdir=base.example_dir('warnings'), copy_srcdir_to_tmpdir=True) def setUp(self, app, status, warning): super(TestWarnings, self).setUp() self.app = app self.app.build() self.status = status.getvalue() self.warning = warning.getvalue() self.html = (app.outdir / 'index.html').read_text() self.soup = BeautifulSoup(self.html, 'html.parser') self.content = str(self.soup) def test_out_of_order(self): """Do we get an out of order naming warning.""" self.assertIn( ("WARNING: Parameters out of order ``name2`` " "should be after ``name``"), self.warning)

commit_message:
Add mesos_slave_executor_environment_variables validate in CLI

mesos_slave_executor_environment_variables is a file path to deliver
the data for mesos executor environment variables, and validate the
file if existing or matching the json form.

Change-Id: Iaeb912184f8789321526887d25e281b5181089ef
Partially-Implements:blueprint mesos-slave-flags

added_lines: def handle_labels(labels): labels = format_labels(labels) if 'mesos_slave_executor_environment_variables' in labels: environment_variables_data = handle_json_from_file( labels['mesos_slave_executor_environment_variables']) labels['mesos_slave_executor_env_variables'] = json.dumps( environment_variables_data) return labels def handle_json_from_file(json_arg): """Attempts to read JSON file by the file url. :param json_arg: May be a file name containing the JSON. :returns: A list or dictionary parsed from JSON. """ try: with open(json_arg, 'r') as f: json_arg = f.read().strip() json_arg = json.loads(json_arg) except IOError as e: err = _("Cannot get JSON from file '%(file)s'. " "Error: %(err)s") % {'err': e, 'file': json_arg} raise exc.InvalidAttribute(err) except ValueError as e: err = (_("For JSON: '%(string)s', error: '%(err)s'") % {'err': e, 'string': json_arg}) raise exc.InvalidAttribute(err) return json_arg

commit_message:
[WIP] Fix incorrect handling of fuel-mirror --replace option

Provide new command option to overwrite all repositories.
Change --replace behaviour to do exactly replacement.

Change-Id: I27d9edbd15ff54feff76c40899ee9e4bee0f7494
Closes-Bug: #1552263

Retire openstack-ansible-py_from_git repository

The content from the openstack-ansible-py_from_git repository
is no longer needed.

This patch implements the retirement of the py_from_git
repository from gate testing as per [1].

Purge nova services for deleted nodes

Deleted hosts create downed services in nova, which should
be cleaned up on the next deploy cycle.

subject: Add option to choose partition alignment mode
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 16:41:49.000000000', 'files': ['fuel_agent/objects/partition/parted.py', 'fuel_agent/tests/test_partition.py', 'fuel_agent/tests/test_manager.py', 'fuel_agent/utils/partition.py', 'fuel_agent/manager.py', 'fuel_agent/tests/test_partition_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent/commit/bf4ed24462375ed3c1741a3a28b5840f582f1588', 'message': "Add option to choose partition alignment mode

Under certain circumstances due to that alignment, the end of
particular partition could cross 1M boundary. And due to actual
partition' bounderies being rounded up, fuel-agent mistakenly
assumes that partition couldn't fit within provided boundaries
and raises errors.WrongPartitionSchemeError.

However, some h/w data storages are well known for reporting
relatively huge optimal IO sizes (16M or even bigger), so the 1M
room can't be enough. Thus, optimal aligning is not an option.
In such cases, it's better to proceed with minimal mode.

It's the minimum aligment needed to align the partition properly
to physical blocks which avoids performance degradation.

Partial-Bug: #1543233
DocImpact

Change-Id: I1dd94731f497f3deb47cec9a23957e3706c2fb3b
(cherry picked from commit af247ea07a469c467b83687013a68b0e3cff05fe)
"}]
commit_message:
Add option to choose partition alignment mode

Under certain circumstances due to that alignment, the end of
particular partition could cross 1M boundary. And due to actual
partition' bounderies being rounded up, fuel-agent mistakenly
assumes that partition couldn't fit within provided boundaries
and raises errors.WrongPartitionSchemeError.

However, some h/w data storages are well known for reporting
relatively huge optimal IO sizes (16M or even bigger), so the 1M
room can't be enough. Thus, optimal aligning is not an option.
In such cases, it's better to proceed with minimal mode.

It's the minimum aligment needed to align the partition properly
to physical blocks which avoids performance degradation.

Partial-Bug: #1543233
DocImpact

Change-Id: I1dd94731f497f3deb47cec9a23957e3706c2fb3b

commit_message:
Enable unallocated drives back

Apparently fix for this bug
https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1258347
turned out to be non-working anyway.
The reason was that 'lvm_meta_pool' sometimes has non-zero size.
Due to its non-zero size the disk wasn't skipped from partitioning,
thus creating a bunch of partitions even on unallocated drives.

Change-Id: Ifaf8cb6a1f9d5010998b89445c3e575f3957411b
Closes-Bug: #1566399
(cherry picked from commit 825468cb3bb1eb1e6a5e7cd665d89496998cdb54)
(cherry picked from commit 6e89fb83e44a7cd3b286308b661f645378576d19)

commit_message:
Add enable-release command

This command enables to deploy an older release of OpenStack
with the upgraded Fuel Master node. Release to enable is
identified by the ID. Administrator's password is required
to access the Fuel API.

Example:

  octane enable-release --id 1 --admin-password admin

Partial-bug: 1567535
Change-Id: I625db20e570b177cb46143818ac65c5d78cda0e2
(cherry picked from commit f73e0c7a9942c2fe211a82dd19107e9fa351e0bd)

commit_message:
Add Non-voting job for nodepool py34

Add py34 non-voting job for nodepool. With python3 fixes being
proposed to nodepool, it is important that there is at least
minimal reporting on success/failure of the py34 checking. As
soon as the test suite can run this can be converted to a voting
job.

Change-Id: I4fc17b67338eb3f36b550fa9f519d439c0d37022

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-11 11:32:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cf863f9822ebe12182f43816e2816f6aababfb8d', 'message': '[WIP] Hyper-V: fix serial console workers spawning

At the moment, we spawn a worker retrieving instance serial
console output when the instance start event is received AND when
the driver receives a power on/reboot request for the instance,
basically attempting to spawn a worker twice.

Although the method which starts the workers is synchronized,

per VMOps instance object.

This change fixes the issue by starting workers only when an instance

attribute.

Change-Id: Ie0c54c2a5e2f90b80792522bf9eabbf07476e1b5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-11 12:17:32.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/hyperv/test_vmops.py', 'nova/virt/hyperv/vmops.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/013b5a6d85c352ad1731fa974ad9b5add4d61815', 'message': '[WIP] Hyper-V: fix serial console workers

console output when the instance start event is received AND when

basically attempting to spawn a worker twice.

Although the method which starts the workers is synchronized,
checking if a worker is already running, it keeps a dict of workers

commit_message:
[WIP] Hyper-V: fix serial console workers

At the moment, we spawn a worker retrieving instance serial
console output when the instance start event is received AND when
the driver receives a power on/reboot request for the instance,
basically attempting to spawn a worker twice.

Although the method which starts the workers is synchronized,
checking if a worker is already running, it keeps a dict of workers
per VMOps instance object.

This change fixes the issue by starting workers only when an instance
power on event in received. Also, workers are now safely stopped.

Change-Id: Ie0c54c2a5e2f90b80792522bf9eabbf07476e1b5

commit_message:
Xenapi: support vgpu via passthrough pci

the implment is to support VGPU via passthrough pci. In order to
support it, it will create fake pci devices for the VGPUs at
Xenapi.

Change-Id: I4c996d9cceb1fe369b1cdff95b1d00fb9c039a52

commit_message:
Refactor get_filtered_hosts in filter host manager

* Removed nested loop in filter algorithm; O(kn) becomes O(k+n)
* Dictionary no longer requires hashing a tuple

Pulled from gate: ovo failure

Change-Id: I2a3bac456d2678eda440b66b30e2e1865991d1b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/211307/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _strip_ignore_hosts(filtered_hosts, hosts_to_ignore): filtered_hosts = [host for host in filtered_hosts if host.host not in hosts_to_ignore] ignored_hosts_str = ', '.join(host.host for host in set(hosts) - set(filtered_hosts)) return filtered_hosts def _match_forced_hosts(filtered_hosts, hosts_to_force): filtered_hosts = [host for host in filtered_hosts if host.host in hosts_to_force] if filtered_hosts: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(filtered_hosts) return filtered_hosts def _match_forced_nodes(filtered_hosts, nodes_to_force): filtered_hosts = [host for host in filtered_hosts if host.nodename in nodes_to_force] if filtered_hosts: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(filtered_hosts) return filtered_hosts ignore_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', [])) force_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('force_hosts', [])) force_nodes = set(filter_properties.get('force_nodes', [])) filtered_hosts = hosts if ignore_hosts: filtered_hosts = _strip_ignore_hosts( filtered_hosts, ignore_hosts) if not filtered_hosts: filtered_hosts = _match_forced_hosts( filtered_hosts, force_hosts) if force_nodes: filtered_hosts = _match_forced_nodes( filtered_hosts, force_nodes) if filtered_hosts: return filtered_hosts filtered_hosts, filter_properties, index)
deleted_lines: def _strip_ignore_hosts(host_map, hosts_to_ignore): ignored_hosts = [] for host in hosts_to_ignore: for (hostname, nodename) in list(host_map.keys()): if host == hostname: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] ignored_hosts.append(host) ignored_hosts_str = ', '.join(ignored_hosts) def _match_forced_hosts(host_map, hosts_to_force): forced_hosts = [] for (hostname, nodename) in list(host_map.keys()): if hostname not in hosts_to_force: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] else: forced_hosts.append(hostname) if host_map: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(forced_hosts) def _match_forced_nodes(host_map, nodes_to_force): forced_nodes = [] for (hostname, nodename) in list(host_map.keys()): if nodename not in nodes_to_force: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] else: forced_nodes.append(nodename) if host_map: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(forced_nodes) ignore_hosts = filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', []) force_hosts = filter_properties.get('force_hosts', []) force_nodes = filter_properties.get('force_nodes', []) name_to_cls_map = {(x.host, x.nodename): x for x in hosts} if ignore_hosts: _strip_ignore_hosts(name_to_cls_map, ignore_hosts) if not name_to_cls_map: _match_forced_hosts(name_to_cls_map, force_hosts) if force_nodes: _match_forced_nodes(name_to_cls_map, force_nodes) if name_to_cls_map: return name_to_cls_map.values() hosts = six.itervalues(name_to_cls_map) hosts, filter_properties, index)

commit_message:
libvirt: Disconnect dm-crypt on instance suspend/stop

Strengthens protection provided by ephemeral storage encryption
feature by disconnecting the dm-crypt device, which provides
access to unencrypted disk, when an encrypted instance is
suspended or stopped.

Co-Authored-By: Joel Coffman <joel.coffman@jhuapl.edu>

Implements: blueprint stop-dmcrypt-on-suspend
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: Idbe37922c5f944e3d567ce16913ce5d87af41fef

commit_message:
Support for new --status parameter to "nova-manage vm list" command

Currently "nova-manage vm list" command is displaying the list of all
vms irrespective of vm_state(active,error..).
As suggested in bug, Added CLI support for new parameter "status" to
filter the VMs based on vm_state in db. If status is not provided,
all vms(active,error..) will be displayed.

Change-Id: I6ebc3ddd4d8c5506684122bcbc12bec551a9cb83
Closes-Bug: #1494841
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/231447/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @args('--status', metavar='<status>', help='Vm state') def list(self, host=None, status=None): if status is not None: filters={'vm_state': status} else: filters={} context.get_admin_context(), filters, expected_attrs=['flavor'])

revisions:

** NOTE: This is a WIP patch, posted to get early feedback **

This patch implements blueprint volume-snapshot-improvements.

Done:
  1) Add new file format querying and reporting to libvirt snapshot code
  2) For liberty, continue to send the 'progress': '90%' flag in
     update_snapshot_status for compatibility.  (Can be removed in the future.)

TODOs:
  1) Add new statuses for progress reporting to libvirt snapshot create/delete
     operations
  2) remove debug only changes

Testign Info:
  1) Related patch: Cinder patch with
     Change-Id: Ifa2836a87271d465af61c4ae4b2018cde0698924
  2) I am testing this with Cinder (with above Change-Id) configured against
     GlusterFS backend

Implements: blueprint volume-snapshot-improvements
Change-Id: Ib5c3de6e757a8cdd098d68ca26194891458b57a9

commit_message:
libvirt: Nova part of volume snapshot improvements

This patch implements blueprint volume-snapshot-improvements :
  * Add new file format querying and reporting to libvirt snapshot code
  * Add code to ensure compatibility with pre-liberty Cinder
  * Add testcases

Testing Info:
  1) Related patch: Ifa2836a87271d465af61c4ae4b2018cde0698924
  2) Tested with Cinder (with above Change-Id) configured against
     GlusterFS backend

Implements: blueprint volume-snapshot-improvements
Change-Id: Ib5c3de6e757a8cdd098d68ca26194891458b57a9

commit_message:
libvirt: Refactor _volume_snapshot_delete function

This patch refactors _volume_snapshot_delete function. It splits
it up into different helper functions such that its easier to
debug, read and maintain the volume snapshot delete flow.

Change-Id: I525dc6f8df236f66b9d81c1510a8822214335526

commit_message:
objects: Add support for OnlineSnapshotInfo object

This patch adds support for OnlineSnapshotInfo object, which provides
the ability to :

  * Add new statuses for progress reporting to libvirt snapshot create/delete
     operations
  * For liberty, continue to send the 'progress': '90%' flag in
     update_snapshot_status

Partially Implements: blueprint volume-snapshot-improvements
Change-Id: Ic0215d5e18fb74ac36fd7b08f8a27ca991e7ebdb

commit_message:
Nova handles servers list with limit=0 different in API and DB

According to the code:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/api/openstack/common.py#n206

when limit = 0, it should apply as max_limit, but currently, in:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#n1930

we directly return [], this is quite different with comment in the api
code.

Change-Id: I42034dbf54a91caafaa313000e825f64c618d2b8

commit_message:
libvirt: refactor config drive live migration test

The code in pre_live_migration() to check whether live migration with
config drive is supported in various cases is complex enough and
heavily enough commented that moving it to a separate function helps
make the code more straightforward to follow.

Also, if we do this, we can create separate tests for the new function
allowing us to test this logic in isolation rather than having to probe
each condition in the context of a full call to pre_live_migration().

Change-Id: I444c596efdf926c62b64fdfddaee4791ad267434
Signed-off-by: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/271458/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Add [pci] group and whitelist_sections to configure PCI passthrough
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-07 03:46:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1421d9d89db692b79dd47e03acc0ce9e145aaaee', 'message': "Add pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections to configure pci passthrough

The current pci_passthrough_whitelist option using embedded json
causes issues for devstack [1]

This proposes 'pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections', which is a config
variable to list a number of individual sections that describe the
same PCI-passthrough options.

At this stage, it converts these back to JSON and passes them to
nova.pci.devspec as usual.  Certainly this interface could be
re-worked to pass a dict directly and avoid this step.  However I
think there is enough to digest with the multiple-section component of
this change, so I'll leave that to a follow-on.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049341.html

Change-Id: I4b860e3f7901b00b1c78f7df1f2219132f347239

This proposes 'pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections', which is a config

This modifies class PciHostDevicesWhiteList() to take both the json

"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2014-11-18 04:39:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2d95b2192b881decc755cdb6dd78f369560bc5a2', 'message': "Add pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections to configure pci passthrough

The current pci_passthrough_whitelist option using embedded json
causes issues for devstack [1]

This proposes 'pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections', which is a config
variable to list a number of individual sections that describe the
same PCI-passthrough options.  For example, two white-lists might be
defined as:

  [DEFAULT]
  pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections = foo_pci, bar_pci

  [foo_pci]
  product_id = 1520
  vendor_id = 8086

  [bar_pci]
  vendor_id = 1137
  product_id = 0071
  address = *:0a:00.*
  physical_network = physnet1

This modifies class PciHostDevicesWhiteList() to take both the json
strings from pci_passthrough_whitelist and dictionaries from
pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections.  Test-cases are updated to
exercise the new argument.

Use of pci_passthrough_whitelist will give a warning message about
it's deprecation, but both methods can co-exist.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049341.html

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4b860e3f7901b00b1c78f7df1f2219132f347239
"}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-11-19 03:56:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/617b9db213e3f4c18703b03b31082ae4e0fa2fdc', 'message': 'Add [pci] group and whitelist_sections to configure PCI passthrough

The current pci_passthrough_whitelist option using embedded json
causes issues for devstack [1].

This proposes a new section [pci] with a config variable
'whitelist_sections' that lists a number of individual sections to
describe the same PCI-passthrough options.  For example, two
white-lists might be defined as:

 [pci]
 whitelist_sections = pci_rule_foo, pci_rule_bar

 [pci_rule_foo]
 product_id = 1520
 vendor_id = 8086

 [pci_rule_bar]
 vendor_id = 1137
 product_id = 0071
 address = *:0a:00.*
 physical_network = physnet1

Note that we enforce the subsections having the "pci_rule_*" prefix to
avoid potential for namespace issues later.

This modifies class PciHostDevicesWhiteList() to take both the json
strings from pci_passthrough_whitelist and dictionaries created from
whitelist_sections.  Test-cases are updated to exercise the new
argument.

Use of pci_passthrough_whitelist will give a warning message about
it's deprecation, but both methods can co-exist.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049341.html

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4b860e3f7901b00b1c78f7df1f2219132f347239

This proposes a new section [pci] with a config variable
'whitelist_sections' that lists a number of individual sections to

avoid potential for namespace issues later.

pci_passthrough_whitelist and dictionaries created from

argument.

it's deprecation, but both methods can co-exist.

commit_message:
Add [pci] group and whitelist_sections to configure PCI passthrough

The current pci_passthrough_whitelist option using embedded json
causes issues for devstack [1].

This proposes a new section [pci] with a config variable
'whitelist_sections' that lists a number of individual sections to
describe the same PCI-passthrough options.  For example, two
white-lists might be defined as:

 [pci]
 whitelist_sections = pci_rule_foo, pci_rule_bar

 [pci_rule_foo]
 product_id = 1520
 vendor_id = 8086

 [pci_rule_bar]
 vendor_id = 1137
 product_id = 0071
 address = *:0a:00.*
 physical_network = physnet1

Note that we enforce the subsections having the "pci_rule_*" prefix to
avoid potential for namespace issues later.

This modifies class WhiteList() to take both the json strings from
pci_passthrough_whitelist and dictionaries created from
whitelist_sections.  Test-cases are updated to exercise the new
argument.

Use of pci_passthrough_whitelist will give a warning message about
it's deprecation, but both methods can co-exist.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049341.html

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4b860e3f7901b00b1c78f7df1f2219132f347239
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/133138/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo.serialization import jsonutils ), cfg.StrOpt('pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections', default='', help='Comma-separated list of sections which define ' 'PCI white-lists.' ), ] """Construct PCI device white-list Concatenate `pci_passthrough_whitelist` :class:`PciHostDevicesWhiteList` JSON option with sections as specified by `pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections`. For example:: [DEFAULT] pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections = foo_pci, bar_pci [foo_pci] product_id = 1520 vendor_id = 8086 [bar_pci] vendor_id = 1137 product_id = 0071 address = *:0a:00.* physical_network = physnet1 """ # pci_passthrough_whitelist is a json-string as described above. # json-strings with quoting, etc, in .ini files can be a bit of a # nightmare for things like devstack's ini-setting functions to # handle. # # So have an alternative of concatenating together pci whitelist # options as defined by the sections provided in comma-separated # list 'pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections' # # To avoid having to re-write large-parts of the back-end at this # point, we convert this back to the json representation and pass # it through. opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('name', default=''), cfg.StrOpt('vendor_id', default=''), cfg.StrOpt('product_id', default=''), cfg.StrOpt('address', default=''), cfg.StrOpt('physical_network', default='') ] sections = [c.strip() for c in CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist_sections.split(',')] json = [] for section in sections: group = cfg.OptGroup(name=section, title="pci_passthrough_%s" % section) CONF.register_group(group) CONF.register_opts(opts, group) details = getattr(CONF, section) # take the details we have in this section, and convert them # back to json representation. details_dict = {} for field in ['name', 'vendor_id', 'product_id', 'address', 'physical_network']: attr = getattr(details, field) if attr: details_dict[field] = attr json.append(jsonutils.dumps(details_dict)) all_whitelists = CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist + json return PciHostDevicesWhiteList(all_whitelists)

commit_message:
Disassociate floating ip when remove fixed ip

When remove fixed ip from an instance, related floating ip
should be disassociated. Otherwise the port_id and fixed_ip
will remain in the floating ip info.

Change-Id: Iadbcee41905a5e17e0c798fe2cbb168f1420b69c
Closes-Bug: #1525101

commit_message:
Libvirt: Pass correct kernel_id and ramdisk_id when do rescue

Currently, when use an image(such as cirros) which has kernel_id and
ramdisk_id to do rescue instance, the instance is failed to boot up.

Closes-Bug: #1530010
Change-Id: Ibcddcd20c62466a6d27bc49b37a0073fc13de64c

commit_message:
Add ContainerFormat field

Add a ContainerFormat field to hold the constants for container formats.
Added a NONE field because ContainerFormat is nullable, but was replaced
with an empty string in I770d394f65e5be6a5f8f36c673806f91509e0abe for
compatibility concerns.

Related-Bug: #1516137
Change-Id: Ifd5e0ccf7aee6f1fc4c57c3856dbdbd4db08a659
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/34/245834/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ContainerFormat(Enum): BARE = 'bare' OVA = 'ova' OVF = 'ovf' RAW = 'raw' TGZ = 'tgz' AMI = 'ami' ARI = 'ari' AKI = 'aki' NONE = '' ALL = (BARE, OVA, OVF, RAW, TGZ, AMI, ARI, AKI, NONE) def __init__(self): super(ContainerFormat, self).__init__( valid_values=ContainerFormat.ALL) class ContainerFormatField(BaseEnumField): AUTO_TYPE = ContainerFormat()

commit_message:
Create 'clustercheck' user only on primary controller.

It's not necessary to do it on all controllers. Part with
creating user in db was excluded from status.pp and it's
called separately on primary controller.

Change-Id: I9eb66b64bcae8077e2a7812ec769ddcadf470719
Closes-Bug: #1580243

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V Cluster implementation

Adds basic support for clustering VMs.

Adds HyperVClusterDriver.
Clusters VMs after they are created.
Unclusters VMs before they are destroyed.

Checks if the VM is clustered before live-migration. If the destination
is in the same cluster, performs clustered live-migration. If not, it
performs regular live-migration.

Partially-Implements: blueprint hyper-v-cluster

Change-Id: I35b112e2a56942737d8c44b6edf3831d7f588e6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/199037/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ A Hyper-V Cluster Nova Compute driver. """ from nova.virt.hyperv import driver from nova.virt.hyperv.cluster import clusterops from nova.virt.hyperv.cluster import livemigrationops from nova.virt.hyperv.cluster import vmops class HyperVClusterDriver(driver.HyperVDriver): def __init__(self, virtapi): super(HyperVClusterDriver, self).__init__(virtapi) self._vmops = self._livemigrationops = vmops.ClusterVMOps()

commit_message:
Hyper-V vTPM Devices

Windows / Hyper-V Server Technical Preview introduced the ability
to attach vTPM devices to the Hyper-V VMs, offering the users the
posibility to use it to enhance their security and system
integrity.

This commit implements adding vTPM devices to instances.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I7728388415e3bef5f312a3630458b89bb1622694
Partially-Implements: blueprint hyper-v-vtpm-devices

commit_message:
Change the default set of tox jobs to run

Select only the tox environments that are the most likely to catch
errors in a change before being submitted for review so that
simply running "tox" is more useful for developers.

Change-Id: I3880aeebb4a4326f774bc6c91f1498fd2d6b77fc

commit_message:
Improve the performance of get instances

When destory the evacuated instances from a host,
it need to get the host's instance which are found on the hypervisor.
If the driver doesn't support uuids listing, it will get all the
instances in db.
So we use evacuate instance's uuid which were evacuated from current
host to filter the instance.

Closes-Bug: #1486026

Change-Id: I6496932f20df7f7819bd640db1e1865b01ac5a8d

commit_message:
Implements proper UUID format for 7 modules from unit/api/openstack/compute/

Currently some of the unittests are using non valid UUID format
for the FieldType UUID.

This is preparation work to add UUID validation in the
oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py.

Without this change adding validation will cause tests to fail.

Change-Id: Ifa69715a8455348956f4b563426928327cd634f9

commit_message:
API sample testing without project_id

This implements an new api paste fixture which swaps out our noauth
middleware with one that doesn't add the project_id into the
urls.

Update the link fixer in the ApiSamples matching code to also update
for optional project_id. This is the least worse approach here,
because if we set request_api_version, then we have to duplicate the
entire template tree as well, which we definitely don't want to do, as
it now correctly handles either url form.

This updates the auth tests to bifurcate with testscenarios instead of
the subclass model, which makes for more consistent tests.

Implements bp:service-catalog-tng

Change-Id: Ib639e92f360499a3292528768bf95aadc8d9e564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/89/256089/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Decrease task timeouts according to actual duration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-24 08:05:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/90d53bb7aad8cd0409f670991245fc6901a5371d', 'message': 'Decrease task timeouts according to actual duration

Most of tasks had timeout equal to 3600 seconds whereas actual duration
is no more than 1 minute.
Minimal timeout is 60 seconds even if task is complete in a few seconds.
New timeout ~ duration * 2.5

Closes-bug: #1558505

commit_message:
Decrease task timeouts according to actual duration

Most of tasks had timeout equal to 3600 seconds whereas actual duration
is no more than 1 minute.
Minimal timeout is 60 seconds even if task is complete in a few seconds.
New timeout ~ duration * 2.5

Change-Id: Iea9ee8f5038f5fcfd9dcdfc2d9ba964eab035549
Closes-bug: #1558505

commit_message:
To allow server search option metadata for non-admin

Currently server search metadata option is silently discarded
for non-admins. so we add a new microversion that will allow this
filter to be applied.

Change-Id: I2483c270ff2e2db4c72920a1e8bc85c612e002a5

subject: WIP: libvirt storage pools initial step
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-17 18:54:10.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/50f844cd018f339014b86905db2e8f946fa05619', 'message': "WIP: libvirt storage pools initial step

This code has never been executed. It undoubtedly contains not only
logical errors, but also syntax errors. Tests haven't been touched at
all, except by automated refactoring. Don't bother looking at the
changes to the tests: they're meaningless.

This change introduces StoragePolicy as a replacement interface for
Backend. There are a few reasons for this change. Firstly, it starts
to centralise code which assumes the placement of disks. This makes
the existing behaviour simpler to follow. Note that this change
attempts to be minimally functional, simply to centralise the existing
behaviour. Sometimes that behaviour doesn't make much sense, for
example the shared storage detection, but we have at least centralised
the problem.

Secondly, we have a goal of changing this placement in moving to
libvirt storage pools. The StoragePolicy interface gives us a hook to
make that change. I anticipate that StoragePolicy will become
LegacyStoragePolicy and will remain in place. We can then use a hook
on storage_policy_for_instance() to select the correct policy for an
existing instance, and to run an upgrade if required.

This change makes 1 slightly less mechanical non-functional change:
Image.import_file -> Image.import_local_file.  This allowed me to
remove an if block on default image type, as well as being more
readable.

This change makes one functional change out of expediency: snapshot
was the only code using disk paths from the libvirt xml rather than
inferring them from nova state. Although the libvirt xml is a source
of absolute truth, if it doesn't correspond to expectations we're
already broken. Rather than maintain 2 very different interfaces, I
have consolidated to using nova state. If this is wrong, it was going
to break somewhere else anyway. It is also simpler to validate.

Going from here, we need to split Image into StoragePool and
StorageVolume. Operations like cache() and create_image() are
operations on the pool. Operations like libvirt_info, resize, and
snapshot_extract are operations on a volume. The StoragePolicy will
create singletons for each pool, and pools will create volumes.

We can then implement new StoragePools which use libvirt, and a new
StoragePolicy which returns them.

StoragePool needs a cleanup_for_instance() method.

N.B. ImageCacheManager is not recoverable. It assumes on-disk layout
everywhere. It is extremely hard to follow. It is extremely hard to
validate. Its structure and code flow are undesirable. It will
continue to manage the 'legacy' storage pools, but the new storage
pools will be managed by a new image cache manager, which will require
a new periodic task.

Change-Id: I500912a10ac948543565801d994a2f49db27880e
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: libvirt storage pools initial step

This code has never been executed. It undoubtedly contains not only
logical errors, but also syntax errors. Tests haven't been touched at
all, except by automated refactoring. Don't bother looking at the
changes to the tests: they're meaningless.

This change introduces StoragePolicy as a replacement interface for
Backend. There are a few reasons for this change. Firstly, it starts
to centralise code which assumes the placement of disks. This makes
the existing behaviour simpler to follow. Note that this change
attempts to be minimally functional, simply to centralise the existing
behaviour. Sometimes that behaviour doesn't make much sense, for
example the shared storage detection, but we have at least centralised
the problem.

Secondly, we have a goal of changing this placement in moving to
libvirt storage pools. The StoragePolicy interface gives us a hook to
make that change. I anticipate that StoragePolicy will become
LegacyStoragePolicy and will remain in place. We can then use a hook
on storage_policy_for_instance() to select the correct policy for an
existing instance, and to run an upgrade if required.

This change makes 1 slightly less mechanical non-functional change:
Image.import_file -> Image.import_local_file.  This allowed me to
remove an if block on default image type, as well as being more
readable.

This change makes one functional change out of expediency: snapshot
was the only code using disk paths from the libvirt xml rather than
inferring them from nova state. Although the libvirt xml is a source
of absolute truth, if it doesn't correspond to expectations we're
already broken. Rather than maintain 2 very different interfaces, I
have consolidated to using nova state. If this is wrong, it was going
to break somewhere else anyway. It is also simpler to validate.

Going from here, we need to split Image into StoragePool and
StorageVolume. Operations like cache() and create_image() are
operations on the pool. Operations like libvirt_info, resize, and
snapshot_extract are operations on a volume. The StoragePolicy will
create singletons for each pool, and pools will create volumes.

We can then implement new StoragePools which use libvirt, and a new
StoragePolicy which returns them.

StoragePool needs a cleanup_for_instance() method.

N.B. ImageCacheManager is not recoverable. It assumes on-disk layout
everywhere. It is extremely hard to follow. It is extremely hard to
validate. Its structure and code flow are undesirable. It will
continue to manage the 'legacy' storage pools, but the new storage
pools will be managed by a new image cache manager, which will require
a new periodic task.

Change-Id: I500912a10ac948543565801d994a2f49db27880e

commit_message:
Support configuration of multiple pci_alias within an array

In Kilo (and earlier), the pci_alias is a json docstring that encodes a
dictionary. This patch adds the list support to pci_alias, and both list and
dict are now supported.

Note: The pci_alias configuration is now aligned with packstack
(see manifests/api.pp in puppet-nova).

DocImpact
Change-Id: I21683daa4fa53d901a9e7dc6dbe366ebcc57bcd5
Closes-Bug: #1513513

added_lines: def test_get_pci_requests_from_flavor_list_format(self): pci_alias = ['[{"name":"QuicAssist",' '"capability_type":"pci",' '"product_id": "4443",' '"vendor_id": "8086",' '"device_type": "ACCEL"},' '{"name": "IntelNIC",' '"capability_type": "pci",' '"product_id": "1111",' '"vendor_id": "8086",' '"device_type": "NIC"}]'] self.flags(pci_alias=pci_alias) expect_request = [ {'count': 3, 'spec': [{'vendor_id': '8086', 'product_id': '4443', 'device_type': "ACCEL", 'capability_type': 'pci'}], 'alias_name': 'QuicAssist'}, {'count': 1, 'spec': [{'vendor_id': '8086', 'product_id': '1111', 'device_type': "NIC", 'capability_type': 'pci'}], 'alias_name': 'IntelNIC'}, ] flavor = {'extra_specs': {"pci_passthrough:alias": "QuicAssist:3, IntelNIC: 1"}} requests = request.get_pci_requests_from_flavor(flavor) self.assertEqual(set([1, 3]), set([p.count for p in requests.requests])) self._verify_result(expect_request, requests.requests)

commit_message:
Reload configuration of nova logging

Allows to change logging config options and apply
them with sending SIGHUP

Depends-On: I1e7a69de169cc85f4c09954b2f46ce2da7106d90
Change-Id: Idb1cd3a9adc75d44aea670305bb338f907b25bcd

added_lines: import functools CONF.set_reload_config_files_hook( functools.partial(logging.setup, CONF, "nova"))

commit_message:
libvirt: Handle unsupported Spice feature per arch

PPC/S390 architectures currently do not support Spice protocol.
So we raise an exception if the feature is enabled in the
configuration and make sure the exception raises for any test
that enables spice.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1494354
Co-Authored-By: Rafael Folco <rfolco@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I823b44ba65ec6c7aabf8f3e1b962b10d4d5257aa

commit_message:
Use ContainerFormat instead of strings

There's a lot of strings out there for using the different container
formats. Well, hopefully this changes all of them over to use
ContainerFormat.

Closes-Bug: #1516137
Change-Id: Ia30597eaeb87520d12d8fe19b25076354007ded0

commit_message:
Fix the rabbitmq crash on CentOS binary and source deploy

this is a wordround fix for the rabbitmq failed when deploy on CentOS in
the CI gate. the ideal fix should set the hostname in setup_gate.sh
script. But it do not work as expect with unknown reason

Partial-Bug: #1581301
Change-Id: Ia692794aadf11d3ebe75e4e2bf6b42d9a5f3996f
(cherry picked from commit c98e9c44f23d14867e4dddea88fe9a9f7aa50dd6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/26/319926/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME(jeffrey4l): do not set two hostnames in oneline. this is a # wordround fix for the rabbitmq failed when deploy on CentOS in the CI # gate. the ideal fix should set the hostname in setup_gate.sh script. # But it do not work as expect with unknown reason echo -e "${ip}\tnode${counter}" >> /tmp/hosts echo -e "${ip}\t$(ssh ${ip} hostname)" >> /tmp/hosts echo "node${counter}" >> ${RAW_INVENTORY}
deleted_lines: if [[ "${DISTRO}" == "Debian" ]]; then ANSIBLE_CONNECTION_TYPE=ssh else ANSIBLE_CONNECTION_TYPE=local fi echo -e "${ip}\tnode${counter} $(ssh ${ip} hostname)" >> /tmp/hosts echo "node${counter} ansible_connection=${ANSIBLE_CONNECTION_TYPE}" >> ${RAW_INVENTORY}

commit_message:
Iteratively generate host states from 'get_all_host_states'

Instead of fetching all the hosts, updating to there most accurate
information and then yielding all known hosts back we can do this
iteratively instead (which avoids needless computation in the case
where a filtering happens early).

This method was previously returning an iterator, which it now does
as well (and iterator/generator is now returned), just that instead of
processing first, then returning that iterator, this processing is
done as needed (more lazily) instead.

Change-Id: Icd255fe5135884b1e32b65dbc09a346a9d415e1c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/224373/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Returns a iterator of HostStates that represents all the hosts the HostManager knows about. Also, during iteration each of th consumable resources in HostState are populated and adjusted based on data in the db. partial_host_states = [] host = compute.host node = compute.hypervisor_hostname state_key = (host, node) self.host_state_map.pop(state_key, None) brand_new = False brand_new = True partial_host_states.append((state_key, service, host_state, brand_new)) # fill the rest of the partial host states in and yield them back for state_key, service, host_state, brand_new in partial_host_states: # We force to update the aggregates info each time a new request # comes in, because some changes on the aggregates could have been # happening after setting this field for the first time host_state.aggregates = [self.aggs_by_id[agg_id] for agg_id in self.host_aggregates_map[ host_state.host]] host_state.update_service(dict(service)) self._add_instance_info(context, compute, host_state) if brand_new: self.host_state_map[state_key] = host_state yield host_state
deleted_lines: """Returns a list of HostStates that represents all the hosts the HostManager knows about. Also, each of the consumable resources in HostState are pre-populated and adjusted based on data in the db. host = compute.host node = compute.hypervisor_hostname state_key = (host, node) self.host_state_map[state_key] = host_state # We force to update the aggregates info each time a new request # comes in, because some changes on the aggregates could have been # happening after setting this field for the first time host_state.aggregates = [self.aggs_by_id[agg_id] for agg_id in self.host_aggregates_map[ host_state.host]] host_state.update_service(dict(service)) self._add_instance_info(context, compute, host_state) return six.itervalues(self.host_state_map)

commit_message:
Introduce Flavor Classes

Introduce the concept of Flavor classes by changes at
Object/DB/SqlAlchemy layer. With this patch a new field
called as 'flavor_class' is introduced to the Flavor
object and DB/SqlAlchemy layer. This change will handle
changes to create, delete, list and show the flavor with
new field flavor class. Please note there will be
seperate client side patch to reflect CLI changes.

Change-Id: I3926e3b3972032b80bc67ecce133f8dc95321f80
Partially-Implements: bp flavor-classes

commit_message:
add script to expire old bug reports

Many OpenStack projects face the issue to have more bug reports than
they can handle with the resources they got. The chances, that the
same setting which leads to the observed issue is still there, is quite
often unlikely. It's better to be explicit and expire old bug reports
which will not get any attention any more.

Change-Id: I3c9c72b528b090647211262d2f0030d66be9857c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/08/321008/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # # Closes Launchpad bug reports which are older than the oldest stable release # (usually 18 months, see DAYS_SINCE_CREATED). It ignores bug reports which: # * have a special comment (see STILL_VALID_FLAG). # * have the status "In Progress" # * have the importance "Wishlist" # # example execution: # $ python expire_old_bug_reports.py nova --no_dry_run # # # Copyright 2016 Markus Zoeller (mzoeller@linux.vnet.ibm.com) # Copyright 2016 Steven Hardy (shardy@redhat.com) # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import argparse import datetime import logging import os import sys import time from launchpadlib.launchpad import Launchpad import lazr.restfulclient.errors LOG_FORMAT = "%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(funcName)s - %(message)s" logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO, format=LOG_FORMAT) LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Expire old bug reports.") parser.add_argument('project_name', help='The Launchpad project name (nova, cinder, ...).') parser.add_argument('--verbose', '-v', help='Enable debug logging.', action="store_true") parser.add_argument('--no_dry_run', help='Execute the expiration for real.', action='store_true') args = parser.parse_args() LOG.info(args) PROJECT_NAME = args.project_name if args.verbose: LOG.setLevel(logging.DEBUG) DAYS_SINCE_CREATED = 30 * 18 # 18 months STILL_VALID_FLAG = "CONFIRMED FOR: %(release_name)s" # UPPER CASE SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES = [] # UPPER CASE class BugReport(object): def __init__(self, link, title, age, bug_task): self.link = link self.title = title.encode('ascii', 'replace') self.age = age self.bug_task = bug_task def __str__(self): data = {'link': self.link, 'title': self.title, 'age': self.age} return "{link} ({title}) - ({age} days)".format(**data) def __cmp__(self, other): return cmp(self.age, other.age) def get_project_client(): cache_dir = os.path.expanduser("~/.launchpadlib/cache/") if not os.path.exists(cache_dir): os.makedirs(cache_dir, 0o700) def no_credential(): LOG.error("Can't proceed without Launchpad credential.") sys.exit() # NOTE(markus_z): possibly you have to install "keyrings.alt": # sudo pip install keyrings.alt launchpad = Launchpad.login_with(PROJECT_NAME + '-bugs', 'production', cache_dir, credential_save_failed=no_credential) project = launchpad.projects[PROJECT_NAME] return project def fill_supported_release_names(): LOG.info("filling supported release names...") lp_project = get_project_client() for s in lp_project.series: if s.active: # stable branch names SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES.append(s.name.upper()) # master name SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES.append(lp_project.development_focus.name.upper()) LOG.info("filled supported release names: %s", SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES) def bug_is_still_valid(bug): for message in bug.messages: for release_name in SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES: flag = STILL_VALID_FLAG % {'release_name': release_name} if flag in message.content: return True return False def get_expired_reports(): LOG.info("getting potentially expired reports...") lp_project = get_project_client() bug_tasks = lp_project.searchTasks( status=["New", "Confirmed", "Triaged"], importance=["Unknown", "Undecided", "Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"], # ignore 'wishlist'; they get special treatment omit_duplicates=True, order_by="datecreated") today = datetime.datetime.today() expired = [] for bug_task in bug_tasks: # remove the timezone info as it disturbs the calculation of the diff diff = today - bug_task.date_created.replace(tzinfo=None) if diff.days < DAYS_SINCE_CREATED: break if bug_is_still_valid(bug_task.bug): continue expired.append(BugReport(link=bug_task.web_link, title=bug_task.bug.title, age=diff.days, bug_task=bug_task)) LOG.info("got %d potentially expired reports." % len(expired)) return expired def expire_bug_report(bug_report): subject = "Cleanup EOL bug report" comment = """ This is an automated cleanup. This bug report got closed because it is older than %(mm)d months and there is no open code change to fix this. After this time it is unlikely that the circumstances which lead to the observed issue can be reproduced. If you can reproduce it, please: * reopen the bug report (set to status "New") * AND add the steps to reproduce the issue (if applicable) * AND leave a comment "CONFIRMED FOR: <RELEASE_NAME>" Only still supported release names are valid (%(supported_releases)s). Valid example: CONFIRMED FOR: %(valid_release_name)s """ % {'mm': DAYS_SINCE_CREATED / 30, 'supported_releases': ', '.join(SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES), 'valid_release_name': SUPPORTED_RELEASE_NAMES[0]} bug_task = bug_report.bug_task bug_task.status = "Won't Fix" bug_task.assignee = None bug_task.importance = "Undecided" try: if args.no_dry_run: bug_task.lp_save() bug_task.bug.newMessage(subject=subject, content=comment) LOG.debug("expired bug report %s" % bug_report) except lazr.restfulclient.errors.ServerError as e: LOG.error(" - TIMEOUT during save ! (%s)" % e, end='') except Exception as e: LOG.error(" - ERROR during save ! (%s)" % e, end='') def main(): if args.no_dry_run: LOG.info("This is not a drill! Bug reports will be closed for real!") time.sleep(4) # in case you wanna ctrl-c this else: LOG.info("This is just a dry-run, nothing will happen.") fill_supported_release_names() expired_reports = get_expired_reports() LOG.info("starting expiration...") for e in expired_reports: expire_bug_report(e) LOG.info("expiration done") if __name__ == '__main__': LOG.info("starting script...") main() LOG.info("end script")

commit_message:
Enable proxy header parsing for heat

For handling the X-Forwarded-Proto, heat uses the http_proxy_to_wsgi
middleware from oslo.middleware. It used to work by default, but now
configuration is required to enable that. We require it since we are
effectively behind a proxy (HAProxy).

Change-Id: I256f27ec6a3f66316ff6aa3f78b2f1ec1472f097
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/84/321984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat::enable_proxy_headers_parsing: true

commit_message:
Update keystone noop tests for wsgi files

Change I03a7a057cae0bf86331191faf47ec394487150a7 is updating the source
path of the wsgi files used to configure keystone under apache. This
change updates the noop tests to just check that the files exist and
configured in the catalog but to exclude the path information.  Once the
change in upstream gets merged, we could add the path information back
in but fuel really shouldn't care where it lives so long as they are
configured.  The upstream tests should be relied on to ensure the
source/destination paths are managed correctly.

Change-Id: I9969185306c77254e781b2c52a6b9bededf40a98
Related-Bug: #1539201

commit_message:
Add test with detached haproxy role

- Add test with external load balancer. Controllers are
from different racks and haproxy is from rack-3
- Separate devops config with appropriate networks
assigned to nodes is used
- Local repos for cluster are used because public networks
are routed without internet connection
- OSTF isn't running because it's not implied to use
separate haproxy

Closes-Bug: #1583530

Change-Id: I0d3647c8eb13159c27e64ddf5925467f451b610c

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Pagination for hypervisor ========================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pagination-for-hypervisor This spec is proposed to support pagination for hypervisor. Problem description =================== When there are thousands of compute nodes, it would be slow to get the whole hypervisor list, and it is bad for user experience to display thousands of items in a table in horizon. Use Cases ---------- * Get paginated compute nodes list when there are too many items. Proposed change =============== Changes are going to be in the following places: * New DB api `compute_node_get_all_by_filters` will be added with params filters, limit, marker, sort_key, and sort_dir, so other filter methods(compute_node_search_by_hypervisor, etc) also can be refactored to use this new db method. * New compute node object `get_by_filters` method will be added which calls the new db api `compute_node_get_all_by_filters`. * Compute api `compute_node_get_all` will be refactored. * REST API microversion will be added for hypervisors list to accept pagination request. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- New Hypervisors list API to support pagination: request:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-hypervisors?marker=2&limit=1 reponse:: { "hypervisors": [ { "hypervisor_hostname": "fake-mini", "id": 3, "state": "up", "status": "enabled" } ] } Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: liyingjun Work Items ---------- 1. Change db api to support pagination params. 2. Add compute node object method and refactor compute api. 3. Add REST API microversion. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The changes will be exercised through unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== New REST API microversion will be added. References ========== None
