subject: VMware: Ensure all the disk files of VM could be deleted along with VM deletion
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-28 03:31:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6e863cee0659c20039571ff4bb080af1f99978a0', 'message': "VMware: Ensure all the disk files of VM could be deleted along with VM deletion

Sometimes openstack users will add disks for VM via vcenter to other datastores which the VM doesn't locate, in this situation, if VM is deleted in openstack, only the disk files in same datastore with VM will got deleted, while the disk files in different datastores with VM won't be deleted. Although it's an un-recommended operation, in order to make the program more robust, we should make all the disk files of VM deleted along with VM deletion.

commit_message:
VMware: Ensure all the disk files of VM could be deleted along with VM deletion

Sometimes openstack users will add disks for VM via vcenter to other datastores
which the VM doesn't locate, in this situation, if VM is deleted in openstack,
only the disk files in same datastore with VM will got deleted, while the disk
files in different datastores with VM won't be deleted. Although it's
an un-recommended operation, in order to make the program more robust,
we should make all the disk files of VM deleted along with VM deletion.

Change-Id: I7b08204e07138f26ccb5cead842fa7bd6dfeb0d9
Closes-Bug: #1498752

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Adds host maintenance implementation

Added implementation for the host_maintenance_mode method in the Hyper-V Driver.

Change-Id: If2280b2c317ffba70c1dccf62fb6473acc6f1bf8
Implements: blueprint hyper-v-host-maintenance
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/204157/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import context from nova import exception from nova import objects from nova.compute import apifrom nova.compute import task_statesfrom nova.compute import vm_states from nova.i18n import _, _LE, _LI, _LWfrom nova.virt.hyperv import vmops self._vmutils = utilsfactory.get_vmutils() self._api = api.API() self._vmops = vmops.VMOps() def host_maintenance_mode(self, host, mode): """Start/Stop host maintenance window. On start, it triggers guest VMs evacuation. """ ctxt = context.get_admin_context(read_deleted="no") if not mode: self._set_service_state(host=host, binary='nova-compute', inactive=False) LOG.info(_LI('Host is off maintenance')) return 'off_maintenance' if mode: self._set_service_state(host=host, binary='nova-compute', inactive=True) vms = self._vmutils.list_instances() for vm in vms: try: instance_uuid = self._vmutils.get_instance_uuid(vm) if not instance_uuid: LOG.info(_LI('Instance %(name)s running on %(host)s ' 'could not be found in database. Skip ' 'migrating this vm to a new host'), {'name': vm, 'host': host}) continue instance = objects.Instance.get_by_uuid(ctxt, instance_uuid) self._api.live_migrate(ctxt, instance, block_migration=True, disk_over_commit=False, host_name=None) LOG.info(_LI('VM %(name)s is being migrated'), {'name': vm}) while True: instance = objects.Instance.get_by_uuid(ctxt, instance_uuid) if instance.task_state == task_states.MIGRATING: time.sleep(1) continue else: break except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Unable to migrate %(vm)s'), {'vm': vm}) instance.host = host instance.vm_state = vm_states.ACTIVE instance.save() vms_uuid_after_migration = self._vmops.list_instance_uuids() remaining_vms = len(vms_uuid_after_migration) if remaining_vms == 0: LOG.info(_LI('All vms have been migrated successfully')) LOG.info(_LI('Host is down for maintenance')) return 'on_maintenance' else: raise exception.MaintenanceModeException(reason='Not all vms have ' 'been migrated: %s remaining instances' % remaining_vms) def _set_service_state(self, host, binary, inactive): "Enable/Disable service on host" ctxt = context.get_admin_context() service = objects.Service.get_by_args(ctxt, host, binary) service.disabled = inactive service.save()

commit_message:
Allow the key manager to default on key size

This allows the keymanager to use the default key size of 256
when requesting a key. The default configuration value of 512
bits for XTS mode encryption is erroneously passed on to the
key manager, 512 bits is not a valid size for AES keys.

The actual desired key length is passed through to dmcrypt
separately, so this change wont effect the actual encryption key
strength used to protect an ephemeral volume.

Change-Id: Ia44b3f84f8f7699c1b712ce6af00c65eedce7a91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/216366/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Only run mistral commands if mistral is enabled

The mistral cli commands to load the workbooks and workflows should only
be run if enable_mistral is true. Otherwise, the commands fail since
mistral is not installed and the undercloud install ultimately fails as
well.

Change-Id: If25fdd8f596d594090cd177e0b024322a4411297
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/35/320035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if eval $(hiera enable_mistral); then # load workflows for workbook in $(mistral workbook-list | grep tripleo | cut -f 2 -d ' '); do mistral workbook-delete $workbook done for workflow in $(mistral workflow-list | grep tripleo | cut -f 2 -d ' '); do mistral workflow-delete $workflow done for workbook in $(ls /usr/share/tripleo-common/workbooks/*); do mistral workbook-create $workbook done fi
deleted_lines: # load workflows for workbook in $(mistral workbook-list | grep tripleo | cut -f 2 -d ' '); do mistral workbook-delete $workbook done for workflow in $(mistral workflow-list | grep tripleo | cut -f 2 -d ' '); do mistral workflow-delete $workflow done for workbook in $(ls /usr/share/tripleo-common/workbooks/*); do mistral workbook-create $workbook done

commit_message:
DB:support for migration objects multi-statuses

This commit adds a method to get migration objects with several
instance_uuids in mutiple states.

It adds migration_get_by_instances_with_multiple_statuses()
in db to avoid multiple database queries for the multiple status.
This method can get migrate objects in the one of several status.
Such as 'post-migrating', 'finished', 'reverting', and 'reverted'.

It also adds get_by_instances_with_multiple_statuses() in object
to avoid multiple database queries for the multiple status.

Co-Authored-By:Kevin_Zheng<zhengzhenyu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: Ia15b6ec653dcf42090dabdcca7e9f8c555369dad
Partial-bug:#1425859
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/169604/56 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def migration_get_by_instance_with_multiple_statuses( context, instance_uuid, statuses): # in order to avoid multiple database queries for the multiple status filter_statuses = [models.Migration.status == value for value in statuses] result = model_query(context, models.Migration, read_deleted="yes"). \ filter_by(instance_uuid=instance_uuid). \ filter(or_(*filter_statuses)). \ first() status = " ".join(statuses) if not result: raise exception.MigrationNotFoundByStatus(instance_id=instance_uuid, status=status) return result

subject: Make pause_server a blocking call
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-09 18:52:20.000000000', 'files': ['nova/compute/rpcapi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2cd2669936e42c346407ef926f819ab00c47da8e', 'message': 'Make pause_server a blocking call

Some drivers do not support pause_instance. Currently the
pause_instance rpc method is a non-blocking cast. This
prevents exceptions from propagating to the user as it
immediately returns an HTTP Accepted response. This patch
makes the pause_instance method a blocking call to allow
exceptions to reach the user.

Change-Id: Ib208bc4ab6b8659ccdfdf5f3411bb7fb8833c2a7
Parital-Bug:#1310131
'}]
commit_message:
Make pause_server a blocking call

Some drivers do not support pause_instance. Currently the
pause_instance rpc method is a non-blocking cast. This
prevents exceptions from propagating to the user as it
immediately returns an HTTP Accepted response. This patch
makes the pause_instance method a blocking call to allow
exceptions to reach the user.

Change-Id: Ib208bc4ab6b8659ccdfdf5f3411bb7fb8833c2a7
Parital-Bug:#1310131
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/243258/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return cctxt.call(ctxt, 'pause_instance', instance=instance)

subject: Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-12 12:44:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7a39621f8ff8e5eec765efb5254b5e195fb7f443', 'message': "Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state

Cannot delete vm instance if duplicate delete requests are sent.

When user sends request to delete an instance, its task_state gets
changed to 'deleting' state. When an instance task_state is already in
'deleting' state and if at that moment the rabbitmq-server get crashed
by some reasons, then the instance task_state remains in 'deleting'
state and user won't be able to delete the instance forever.

At this moment, there is only one way to delete the instances, whose
task_state is 'deleting' state, by restarting the nova-compute
services where these instances are running.

To avoid restarting the nova-compute service manually, modified the
force-delete api to allow instance deletion irrespective of
instance task_state.

Change-Id: I302a3a21fd117df7edfd0c4d8a40fd0efb4c794e
Closes-Bug: 1308342
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-13 09:12:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ec4ebf30f1208ea2b82e4525c60f1766ee0edddd', 'message': "Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state

Cannot delete vm instance if duplicate delete requests are sent.

When user sends request to delete an instance, its task_state gets
changed to 'deleting' state. When an instance task_state is already in
'deleting' state and if at that moment the rabbitmq-server get crashed
by some reasons, then the instance task_state remains in 'deleting'
state and user won't be able to delete the instance forever.

At this moment, there is only one way to delete the instances, whose
task_state is 'deleting' state, by restarting the nova-compute
services where these instances are running.

To avoid restarting the nova-compute service manually, modified the
force-delete api to allow instance deletion irrespective of
instance task_state.

commit_message:
Allow force-delete irrespective of VM task_state

Cannot delete vm instance if duplicate delete requests are sent.

When user sends request to delete an instance, its task_state gets
changed to 'deleting' state. When an instance task_state is already in
'deleting' state and if at that moment the rabbitmq-server get crashed
by some reasons, then the instance task_state remains in 'deleting'
state and user won't be able to delete the instance forever.

At this moment, there is only one way to delete the instances, whose
task_state is 'deleting' state, by restarting the nova-compute
services where these instances are running.

To avoid restarting the nova-compute service manually, modified the
force-delete api to allow instance deletion irrespective of
instance task_state.

Added new instance task_state 'force-deleting' (which is set if instance
is deleted using force_delete api) to ignore duplicate force-delete
requests and still allowing retry on regular delete request.

Change-Id: I302a3a21fd117df7edfd0c4d8a40fd0efb4c794e
Closes-Bug: 1431860
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/163798/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (delete_type != 'force_delete' and original_task_state in (task_states.DELETING, task_states.SOFT_DELETING)): def _delete_instance(self, context, instance, delete_type='delete'): self._delete(context, instance, delete_type, self._do_delete, @check_instance_state(task_state=None, must_have_launched=False) self._delete_instance(context, instance, 'force_delete')
deleted_lines: if original_task_state in (task_states.DELETING, task_states.SOFT_DELETING): def _delete_instance(self, context, instance): self._delete(context, instance, 'delete', self._do_delete, @check_instance_state(must_have_launched=False) self._delete(context, instance, 'force_delete', self._do_delete, task_state=task_states.DELETING)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-29 17:53:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e14cae69431367800435c00827d1a67d83d0451c', 'message': 'Use psutil and TERM to KILL backoff loop

commit_message:
libvirt: Use psutil and TERM to KILL backoff loop

Instead of directly trying to SIGKILL a active rsync/scp process
it is nicer to first try to give that process a SIGTERM so that it
can shutdown in a nice manner (then wait for it to respond) and then
if it still has not responded attempt to SIGKILL it. This adds that
loop to do just this.

It also moves toward using psutil (already a requirement) to do the
process term/kill and process location work, since that library already
does this in a way that works across operating systems and ensures that
pids are not reused while the kill/term loop is active.

Change-Id: I963b396f44a1b0cc05cf8697416772f55a0465c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/218597/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import psutil from six.moves import range as compat_rangedef _try_term_then_kill(pid, wait_delay=0.1, interrupt_attempts=3): """Tries to SIGTERM the pid, then if that doesn't work SIGKILL(s) it.""" try: p = psutil.Process(pid) except psutil.NoSuchProcess: return True for i in compat_range(0, interrupt_attempts): LOG.debug("Attempt %s to terminate process '%s'", i + 1, p) try: p.terminate() except psutil.NoSuchProcess: return True else: LOG.debug("Sleeping for %s seconds before next" " attempt to terminate process '%s'", wait_delay, p) try: p.wait(timeout=wait_delay) except psutil.TimeoutExpired: pass else: return True try: p.kill() except psutil.NoSuchProcess: return True else: return False has_died = _try_term_then_kill(pid) except psutil.Error as exc: LOG.error(_LE('Failed to kill process %(pid)s ' 'due to %(reason)s, while deleting the ' 'instance.'), {'pid': pid, 'reason': exc}, instance=instance) else: if not has_died: LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to kill a long running process " "%(pid)s related to the instance when " "deleting it."), {'pid': pid}, instance=instance) else: self.remove_job(instance, pid)
deleted_lines: import errno import os import signal # Try to kill the process os.kill(pid, signal.SIGKILL) except OSError as exc: if exc.errno != errno.ESRCH: LOG.error(_LE('Failed to kill process %(pid)s ' 'due to %(reason)s, while deleting the ' 'instance.'), {'pid': pid, 'reason': exc}, instance=instance) try: # Check if the process is still alive. os.kill(pid, 0) except OSError as exc: if exc.errno != errno.ESRCH: LOG.error(_LE('Unexpected error while checking process ' '%(pid)s.'), {'pid': pid}, instance=instance) else: # The process is still around LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to kill a long running process " "%(pid)s related to the instance when " "deleting it."), {'pid': pid}, instance=instance) self.remove_job(instance, pid)

commit_message:
Remove SoftDeleteMixin from BandwidthUsage

This class is never soft-deleted, so it doesn't need the mixin.

It should be OK to remove the columns from the model (by removing the
mixin) because they have not been used for over a cycle (in fact, ever).
Doing this should result in an automatic schema contraction.

By the same token, it should be OK to remove shadow_bw_usage_cache as
nothing has ever been soft-deleted so this table should be empty.

Change-Id: Ib6011a89f73d401334874d719721e41dc0483dc2

commit_message:
xenapi: add created tag on cached images

Adds created time string on cached vdi. This allows
for time based cleanup of old cache. Current method
of cleanup can be modified to implement a time based
cleanp such that image > X seconds can be cleaned.

Change-Id: I76e78fbb92faefe30842ac08f426760ac3a17769

commit_message:
XenAPI Driver: set capabilites explicitly

This commit sets XenAPI Driver capabilities dict explicitly and
enables supports_recreate, which is needed for BFV evacuate.

Change-Id: I6e4d00dbc07f3893dccc5ddd1aa96b552693f12c
Closes-bug: #1477684
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/206288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: capabilities = { "has_imagecache": False, "supports_recreate": True, "supports_migrate_to_same_host": False }

subject: add support for muti_statuses_query from migration

commit_message:
add support for muti_statuses_query from migration

This commit adds a method to get migration
objects in the one of several status from a list of instances
It adds get_by_instances_with_multiple_statuses() in object to
to avoid multiple database queries for the multiple status.

Co-Authored-By: Kevin_Zheng <zhengzhenyu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: If3cbe9da92d0f05677df9dca07c15b4e497546d2
Closes-Bug: #1425859

Assuming migration.", instance=instance) new_instance_type = current_instance_type else: new_instance_type = flavors.get_flavor_by_flavor_id( flavor_id, read_deleted="no") if (new_instance_type.get('root_gb') == 0 and current_instance_type.get('root_gb') != 0 and not self.is_volume_backed_instance(context, instance)): reason = _('Resize to zero disk flavor is not allowed.') raise exception.CannotResizeDisk(reason=reason) same_instance_type = (current_instance_type['id'] == new_instance_type['id']) if same_instance_type and flavor_id and self.cell_type != 'compute': raise exception.CannotResizeToSameFlavor() if flavor_id: deltas = compute_utils.upsize_quota_delta(context, new_instance_type, current_instance_type) try: quotas = compute_utils.reserve_quota_delta(context, deltas, instance) except exception.OverQuota as exc: quotas = exc.kwargs['quotas'] overs = exc.kwargs['overs'] usages = exc.kwargs['usages'] headroom = self._get_headroom(quotas, usages, deltas) (overs, reqs, total_alloweds, useds) = self._get_over_quota_detail(headroom, overs, quotas, deltas) LOG.warning(_LW("%(overs)s quota exceeded for %(pid)s," " tried to resize instance."), {'overs': overs, 'pid': context.project_id}) raise exception.TooManyInstances(overs=overs, req=reqs, used=useds, allowed=total_alloweds) else: quotas = objects.Quotas(context=context) if not flavor_id: self._record_action_start(context, instance, instance_actions.MIGRATE) else: self._record_action_start(context, instance, instance_actions.RESIZE)

commit_message:
Cells: Decrement available slots

On build, decrement a cell's available ram slots. Using the scheduler_count
configuration option the available capacity per cell is effectively divided
per scheduler. This prevents multiple schedulers from flooding the same cell
with build requests that exceed the capacity. Iff a scheduler has consumed
the entirety of the capacity allocated to it, begin consuming per cell
capacity reserved for other schedulers.

Scheduling larger instances will consume both the larger slot as well as
each of the smaller slots reported (e.g. a build request for a 2048 slot
will also consume two 1024 slots and four 512 slots).

Co-author: Ben Roble <ben.roble@rackspace.com>
Co-author: John Garbutt <john.garbutt@rackspace.co.uk>

Implements: blueprint cells-decrement-ram-slots

Change-Id: I1225337382241772da903b80f04c348e99210e1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/197425/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _decrement_cell_slot_count(self, ctxt, target_cell, build_inst_kwargs): filter_properties = build_inst_kwargs['filter_properties'] instance_type = filter_properties['instance_type'] memory_needed = str(instance_type['memory_mb']) # TODO(johngarbutt) do we need cell-db-sync lock? # NOTE(johngarbutt) this would work better if # state_manager state was shared between processes # or is only accessed by a single process ram_free = target_cell.capacities.get('ram_free', {}) units_by_mb = ram_free.get('units_by_mb', {}) units_free = units_by_mb.get(memory_needed, 0) if units_free > 0: units_by_mb[memory_needed] = units_free - 1 self._decrement_cell_slot_count(ctxt, target_cell, build_inst_kwargs)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-25 21:50:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/450e636ddd7b5eae3b2f21beef0b3c173df4a8e5', 'message': 'Cells: limit slots by io_ops

Currently due to the iops scheduler filter, we have an effective capacity that
is lower than our actual capacity. This patch fixes the issue by accounting
for the rackspace_filter io_ops limits in the slots reported up to the cells
scheduler.

Maintainability: This is a hotpatch for autoscale, and while it will help
relieve the issue, upstream would not accept a fix like this without
discussion/spec/bp. To be upstreamed, more details/collaboration is needed, or
this would possibly be resolved by a move to cells v2. Ultimately a good
method of removing this patch is not clear but unfortunately this is a
necesary hotfix.

Co-author: John Garbutt
rm11852

commit_message:
Cells: report capped units and max builds

Currently due to the io_ops and num_instances scheduler filters, we have an
effective capacity that is lower than our actual capacity. Account for the
limits as capped units reported up to the cells scheduler. Also report the
max builds a cell can support at the given time.

Implements: blueprint cells-report-capped-units-and-max-builds

Change-Id: I9ea2179e61244b23b9301e9bff48427eae610621

added_lines: import json from heat.common import exception from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import clients from heat.engine import scheduler class VolumeBackup( resource.Resource ): PROPERTIES = ( AVAILABILITY_ZONE, SIZE, VOLUME_ID, NAME, DESCRIPTION, CONTAINER, METADATA ) = ( 'availability_zone', 'size', 'volume_id', 'name', 'description', 'container', 'metadata' ) properties_schema = { AVAILABILITY_ZONE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, 'The availability zone in which the backup will be created.' ), SIZE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.NUMBER, 'The size of the backup in GB.', constraints = [constraints.Range( min = 1 ), ] ), VOLUME_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, 'The volume to create the backup from.' ), NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, 'A name used to distinguish the backup.' ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, 'A description of the backup.' ), CONTAINER: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, 'Container of the backup.' ), METADATA: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.MAP, 'Key/value pairs to associate with the backup.' ), } attributes_schema = { 'availability_zone': 'The availability zone in which the backup is located.', 'size': 'The size of the backup in GB.', 'volume_id': 'The volume backup was created from, if any.', 'name': 'Name of the backup.', 'description': 'Description of the backup.', 'container': 'Container of the backup.', 'metadata': 'Key/value pairs associated with the backup.', } def _display_name( self ): name = self.properties[self.NAME] if name is None: name = self.physical_resource_name() return name def _display_description( self ): description = self.properties[self.DESCRIPTION] if description is None: description = self.physical_resource_name() return description def handle_create( self ): volume_id = self.properties[self.VOLUME_ID] name = self._display_name() description = self._display_description() backup = self.cinder().backups.create( volume_id, name = name, description = description, container = self.properties[self.CONTAINER] ) self.resource_id_set( backup.id ) return backup def check_create_complete( self, backup ): backup.get() if backup.status == 'available': return True elif backup.status == 'creating': return False else: raise exception.Error( backup.status ) def _resolve_attribute( self, name ): vol = self.cinder().backups.get( self.resource_id ) if name == 'metadata': return unicode( json.dumps( vol.metadata ) ) return unicode( getattr( vol, name ) ) @scheduler.wrappertask def _delete( self ): if self.resource_id is not None: try: backup = self.cinder().backups.get( self.resource_id ) backup.delete() while True: yield backup.get() except clients.cinderclient.exceptions.NotFound: self.resource_id_set( None ) def handle_delete( self ): delete_task = scheduler.TaskRunner( self._delete ) delete_task.start() return delete_task def check_delete_complete( self, delete_task ): return delete_task.step() def resource_mapping( ): return { 'OS::Cinder::VolumeBackup': VolumeBackup, }

subject: Fix error in restarting SoftwareDeployment resource
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-29 08:03:35.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/software_deployment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/385913f4b14db3f491d4f69a84049c2ffd396ddd', 'message': "Fix error in restarting SoftwareDeployment resource

During restart resource by stack.restart_resource(), it will destroy
and recreate the resource. For SoftwareDeployment resource,it deletes
the resource from db during delete process, and then it comes to
recreate it, and because its resource_id is still the previous one,
not none, so SoftwareDeployment try to update it, then failed at
show_software_deployment() due to the resource can't be found.

Change-Id: I4051e50884ab300a11d6b1a5904ad182d63c9d2a
Closes-Bug: #1511246
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error in restarting SoftwareDeployment resource

During restart resource by stack.restart_resource(), it will destroy
and recreate the resource. For SoftwareDeployment resource,it deletes
the resource from db during delete process, and then it comes to
recreate it, and because its resource_id is still the previous one,
not none, so SoftwareDeployment try to update it, then failed at
show_software_deployment() due to the resource can't be found.

Change-Id: I4051e50884ab300a11d6b1a5904ad182d63c9d2a
Closes-Bug: #1511246

commit_message:
Release python-cinderclient 1.7.1

Release 1.7.0 introduced a change to be able to
specify more options when uploading a volume image.
The options were added in a backward incompatible
way, making this break previous deployments.

This release fixes that call to allow the client to
work with older versions.

Change-Id: I47c17a4d283123ebdfb98d35f8107baa246d26a5

commit_message:
Refactorize Puppet versions testing matrix

* Run puppet-unit-latest only on master, as non-voting.
  The goal of this job is to test very latest versions of Puppet and
  provide early feedback.
* On master (current Newton), stop running unit tests on 3.3, 3.4, 3.7
  and 4.0. A recent poll showed that 3.6, 3.8 and recent 4.x were the
  most used by our community.
* On stable/mitaka and master (current Newton), start running unit tests
  on 4.5 (latest version) as voting.

Coverage summary:
Liberty: 3.3, 3.4, 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 4.0
Mitaka: 3.3, 3.4, 3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 4.0, 4.5
Newton: 3.6, 3.8, 4.5 and latest (non-voting)

Change-Id: I093f2791723172b4995adc5b73fa5e23623e0614

commit_message:
puppet/experimental: deploy puppet4

We're working on getting Puppet Beaker jobs working on Ubuntu Xenial.

Current jobs are broken because:
* https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/BKR-821
* Puppetlabs does not package Puppet3 for Ubuntu Xenial

This patch aims to deploy Puppet4 so we can make progress on running
beaker jobs on Ubuntu Xenial until BKR-821 is fixed (we'll probably try
to run Puppet3 again on Xenial).

Change-Id: Id0573e491bba954ab87b8b3905b555c77c361858
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/63/320663/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # deploy puppet4 on experimental beaker jobs if [ "{job-suffix}" == "nv" ]; then PUPPET_INSTALL_TYPE=agent fi

Change-Id: Iff9180054bf14495e5667af00ae2fafbdbc23791
'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-11-24 20:05:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/012f3c6b24f804f688c301264a8f1f388daf9d16', 'message': 'Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
in a temporary directory and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).

Change-Id: Iff9180054bf14495e5667af00ae2fafbdbc23791
'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-11-24 20:43:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/67698448998dbb6659e0d8cc97101bdbfa3989d4', 'message': 'Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
in a temporary directory and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).

Change-Id: Iff9180054bf14495e5667af00ae2fafbdbc23791
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-11-25 01:53:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/216a5936179dfc4ca398a0c91c44208b9b7454dc', 'message': 'Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
in a temporary directory and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).

Change-Id: Iff9180054bf14495e5667af00ae2fafbdbc23791

commit_message:
Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
using a random socket and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).
